When I was about fourteen years old, a friend at school who spent the summer holidays in Michigan set me up with an American pen-pal. This is not an episode I am proud to remember. In fact, one day I hope to be able to forget it: the ensuing correspondence, after all, ran to only three pages, and no one from the Oxford University Press has, as yet, suggested collecting it in book form with scholarly apparatus and footnotes. But for the time being I need to get it off my chest, so here it is. The trouble was, Kerry-Anne was an everyday teenager with no literary pretentions - and for some reason this made the precocious blue-stocking in me feverishly uncomfortable. When her first letter arrived (she had pluckily set the ball rolling) I was absolutely appalled. It was in huge handwriting, like an infant's. It was on pink paper, with carefree spelling errors - and where the dots over the I's ought to be, there were bubbles . "I am strawberry blonde," she wrote, "with a light dusting of freckles." In hindsight I see it was unrealistic to expect a pen-pal from the 8th grade in Detroit to write like Samuel Johnson. But on the other hand, what earthly use to me was this vapid mousey moron parading a pigmentational handicap? To this day I am ashamed of what I did to Kerry-Anne (who unsurprisingly never wrote back). I replied to her childish letter on grown-up deckled green paper with a fountain pen...I know I deliberately dropped the word "desultory," and I think I may even have used some French...The main reason I recall this shameful teenage epiphany, however, is that in my mission to blast little Kerry-Anne out of the water, I pulled out (literally) all the stops: I used a semicolon. "I watch television in a desultory kind of way; I find there is not much on," I wrote. And it felt so good. It felt fantastic. It was like that bit in Crocodile Dundee when our rugged hero scoffs at the switchblade of his would-be mugger, and produces a foot-long weapon of his own, "Call that a knife? THAT's a KNIFE." I think I liked this part so much because I did something very similar to my freshman roommate.

This morning when I walked out of the parking center into the waiting area for the tram, I saw someone I went to high school with. I've seen her a couple of times before, and seen her give me that "I think I know you" look, which I'm sure I've given her myself. Even though my look was a "I DO know you but hope to god you don't remember me because I don't want to talk to you" look. So even though I've seen her about five times now, I've managed to avoid conversation or acknowledging her. I didn't think I'd get away with it again today. I walked out. I saw her. She saw me. I sat down and pretended to be looking at something interesting on my cell phone. Then this older woman I talk to sometimes waiting for the tram came out and said hi. I said hi. She said she was walking. I said, "Oh! I'll go with you!" And I managed to avoid my past once again. See, this girl I'm avoiding was someone who was friends with the friends I ate lunch with in high school. I was one of those people who hated cliques so much, she managed to be a part of about five different ones just to avoid association. At lunch, I hung out with the Christian good girl crowd. In class, I was part of the smart kid group and only talked to people who were in at least as many AP classes as me (mostly because they were the only people in my classes). And then I hung out with the journalism dorks, the writing club nerds and the pep squad. Yeah, the pep squad. Me, a person so far from peppy I don't think you could get there by any means of transportation. I still keep in touch (sort of) with some of the Christian crowd. The girl who used to be this girl I'm avoiding's best friend told me that she had run into a bad crowd. While I'm a little curious what that means by her standards, I just don't want to deal with this person at all. She was the worst kind of airhead 6 years ago and I'm sure that couldn't have changed much.

There are some days that I question my belief in God. It just seems sometimes like we're completely alone in the world. I start to believe that whole science theory over what the Bible has to say about the creation of earth. Reading The Da Vinci Code didn't help. I wanted to believe that everything in the book was true, that the New Testament was complete bunk. The last month and a half has kind of proved to me that there has to be a God of some kind. But it's not a kind god, and there is no way God is female. If God was female, I would not have had to have my butt cut open. I would not have been on antibiotics that made me puke more than 30 times in two days. I would not have scraped the side of my car on a pole. I would not have crunched my bumper hitting the same pole two weeks later. And I wouldn't have run over a nail and gotten a flat tire. The last two things happened in the last two days. These events have made me realize that there has to be a god, and he is vengeful. I am not sure what I did, but I'm sure that it must have been bad. Maybe it's the way I steer my car with my middle fingers all the way home from work just so I don't have to make an effort to cuss out the people who cut me off or break suddenly and cause my CDs to fly off the front seat onto the floor where I can't reach them. Maybe it's because I stopped praying. Or maybe it's the 15 years of my life I haven't gone to church. Whatever it was, I think I've been punished enough now. God can move on to another victim now.

I was editor of the school newspaper when I was in high school. One of the perks of being an editor was that I could write editorials about any silly thing I wanted. One issue I wrote an editorial about how silly I thought school dances were. I said something about how they were excuses for teenage girls to play Cinderella, get all gussied up and go out to dance. I went on to say it was a waste of time and money and that I could have much more fun going to Burger King and ice skating with my friends. I had countless "normal" high school girls come up to me telling me they disagreed with my column. I said, "well, isn't that the whole point of an editorial? You don't have to agree with it." They didn't seem to agree, and one person refused to talk to me for a week and a half. What a loss. Since then, I've realized that I have tons of opinions. Some I share with other people, some I don't. I really don't care if people agree with me or not...I say what I think. Some people might call me blunt, but I think it's what makes me me.

Since when do college freshmen need their mommies and daddies to go with them to orientation? I work at a university, and it being mid-summer, the new freshmen (or ants as I like to call them, because when all the students are here, they look like ants when I look down from my office window) are visiting for orientation. Nearly all of them are accompanied by one or more parent. My mom and dad did not go with me to my college orientation. Now, I've only been out of school for two years, so this change must be relatively new. The only contribution my parents made to my college career was paying the monthly tuition payments. I filled out the application, I registered for classes and attended orientation day by myself, I paid for my books, I attended classes, took exams and graduated basically on my own. Granted, without my parents' monetary contribution, I would not be sitting here typing this to you. And, yes, they must have done something right for me to be accepted into college in the first place. But that's where their involvement stopped. (With the exception of helping me move in and out what feels like a million times -- Thanks, Mom and Dad). Anyway, so there are all these kids here with their parents. Like it's that difficult for an 18-year-old to go meet with an advisor to discuss what classes they should take. I guess they all need a hand to hold while they take a campus tour from a threatening student. What's worse than all this is that I heard from one of the admission counselors that parents call him up saying things like, "I'm thinking of enrolling my son in the engineering program." Um, excuse me? YOU'RE thinking of enrolling your son? I thought that in this country, people were considered adults at age 18. So you'd think that the choice of what college to go to, what to major in, and even the decision to go to college at all would be the STUDENT'S. If my parents had told me where I was going to school, or applied for me, I would have been pissed. I'd be working at a movie theater or something just to spite them. Maybe today's youth (haha, saying that makes me laugh and feel old at the same time) needs some extra guidance. Maybe they're incapable of doing anything on their own. Maybe their parents will write their theses for them when they get to graduate school.
